Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I completed for you, my Sons, this book, which is the last in science within medicine with its complement, and reached the end thereof from his explanations and his own declarations, it seemed fitting to me to complete it for you together with this Treatise which is a part of operation, that is, surgery by hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since the operation with an extended hand lies in our region and time, and was completely private until perhaps the science of it perished and its trace was cut off: and there remained from it nothing but precise descriptions in ancient books, which were altered by hands: and they fell into error and hesitation until their intentions were closed and his power stretched out: It seemed fitting to me to vivify it with the arrangement of this Treatise within it according to the way of position and declaration and abbreviation: and to provide forgiveness with the forms of the cautery tools and other instruments of the operation: which is done by addition of its declaration and hastening what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why a good artisan with his hand is not found in our time is: because the art of medicine is long, and it is necessary for its author to exercise himself in the science of anatomy before that which Galen narrated, until he knows the nourishment of the members, their forms, their conjunctions, and separations, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, sinews, their numbers, their exit, and veins, their pulsatile and quiet states, and the places of their exits.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for that reason, Hippocrates said, that the name with a title is much, and with an act is little, and especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have indeed already spoken of that in the introduction to this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since he who is not knowledgeable of what we have said about anatomy will not be profited, but will rather fall into error, as men are killed thereby: as I have seen many among those who are trained in this science and boast of it without knowledge and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	Because I have seen a stupid physician cut into a scrofulous boil on a woman's neck, and he severed certain arteries in the neck: wherefore the woman's blood flowed until she died in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen another physician who attempted to extract a stone from a man who had it at an advanced age, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	Therefore he reached for it and extracted it along with a fragment of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Wherefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I myself had indeed been called to extract it: and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the patient that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I have seen another physician who received payment from a Duke of our land for his medical services: and it happened that a black eunuch, who was with him, sustained a fracture in his thigh near the heel: and the physician, out of his ignorance, hastened and bound the fracture over the wound with bandages and strong ligatures, and did not release the wound from its constriction.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he discharged him according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Then he discharged him after a few days, and commanded him not to release the bandages: and he remained thus until the boil on his thigh and foot developed, and he came to his demise.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was therefore called to him, and hastened to release the ligament; and there ensued tranquility, and he escaped from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	Verily the corruption was already confirmed in the member: and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore the corruption ceased to wander through the member, until it perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who pierced the cancerous abscess: and it became ulcerated after a few days, until the evil increased with its lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	For when the cancer is pure from the black bile, then it is not proper to reach it with iron at all, unless it be in a member that can tolerate its being cut away entirely.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for this reason, my Son, you must know that the operation with the hand is divided into two parts: namely, the operation which is associated with safety; and the operation from which danger arises in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already excited in every place of this book where the operation comes which is accompanied by terror and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore you must beware of it and dismiss it, so that the foolish may not find a way to speak about it and dishonour it.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore receive the measure with solicitude and protection, and your infirm ones with facility and firmness, and use the better way conducted by the grace of God for salvation and a worthy succession: and dismiss terrifying illnesses difficult to cure: and lift your souls from that which makes you fear, that hesitation may not enter upon you in your faith and welfare.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more conducive to your glory, and higher in this world, and finally to your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galenus has already said this in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat evil diseases: lest you be called evil physicians.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	Now we have divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	First Chapter.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	On the Cautery with fire, and the Cautery with sharp medicine, divided and arranged from head to feet, and the forms of the instruments and tools of the cauterization: and everything necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Second Chapter.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On incision and puncture, phlebotomy and venesection, and wounds: and the extraction of arrows and similar objects: and the entire chapter, arranged by the forms of the instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Third Chapter.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration, dislocation, and the cure of torsion and similar cases: the chapter, arranged from head to feet, and by the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God Alone Be Glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	Albucasis's Surgery Book.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the Advantage and Harm of the Cautery: for which temperaments it is suitable, and at what time: whether to be performed with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Head I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But Firstly Before I remind you of the operation with him, I must say what his horses are like, and what injuries he causes: and in which temperament he is exhibited.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say that the discourse concerning the quality of Cauterius' horses and his injuries is a lengthy and subtle science, a secret and hidden matter.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	And many wise men spoke on this matter, and disagreed. And I find their words insufficient for me, fearing the lengthening of the discourse.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say that Cauterius acts universally on all temperaments, whether they are with matter or without matter: excepting two temperaments, which are the hot temperament without matter, and the dry temperament without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	In the hot and dry temperament with matter, they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	For some said that Cauterius is beneficial in the hot and dry temperament with matter.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the contrary, namely that Cauterius is not suitable in illness arising from heat and dryness: for the nature of fire is heat: and it is不适宜的，用干热和干热来治愈由干热引起的疾病。
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the contrary said that by means of Cauterius, benefit is derived in every hot and dry illness that occurs in human bodies: for when you compare the human body and its humours to the temperament of fire, you find the human body to be cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I indeed say by his word: because from experience he has shown me that this is so oftentimes.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitioultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in seipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	From the other complexions there is no fear for you: and especially in cold and moist diseases.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all physicians have agreed upon them: and they did not dissent from the use of cauterization in these diseases.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And you know, my sons, that from the secret of cure through cauterization with fire, and the excellence of cauterization with burning medicine, it is clear: for fire is simple, its action reaching only to the part cauterized, and it does not harm another connected part unless to a very small degree.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	And the action of burning medicine reaches that which is detached from the limbs: and perhaps it causes disease in another limb that is difficult to cure, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	But fire, because of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not cause it unless there is excess.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	And we have come to know this through experience, because of the length of service and study with the art, and the position above the truth of things: and for this reason we are brief in our discourse.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not the case, because it is not permissible for my book to include a secret concerning fire, and the quality of its operation in the expulsion from bodies of what it expels, by which it alleviates diseases, I would demonstrate this philosophically to your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, my children, that they differ in the time at which it is proper to make a cautery, and prefer the true time.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that a cautery is proper at all times: for harm occurring due to timing is overcome by the benefit drawn with the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if the cautery is due to pains from necessary, strong, and rapid pains that do not tolerate delay: for fear is had that some greater harm may occur, which would be more detrimental than the minor harm caused by waiting.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let it not enter your minds, my children, that which they do not consider, except the common and stupid doctors, namely, that the disease cured by cautery is not always subject to recurrence: and they put forth this consequence, and things are not as they imagine: for cautery is used only in place of medicine which alters the complexion and dries up the humors which are the causes of pain.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Yet the cautery surpasses medicine through its speed of action and the strength of its operation and the vehemence of its dominion: and it is possible that the disease returns at some hour of time according to the condition of the patient, the state of his illness, and its strength: and what is prepared in his body from the aggregation of excesses within him: and what reaches him in acquiring it from food and similar causes, unless the disease arises in which cautery is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A disease subtle in member of few superfluities and humours, like the cautery of a tooth, on account of pain, and similar to that, it is possible for that pain not to return therein.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this happens in few.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But the speech of the common people again is that the cautery is the last medicine: this is a correct speech: not what they intend in it: for they believe that it is not a cure which can compare with medicine nor with other things after the occasion of the cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the truth is contrary to that and their intent, for the cautery is the last remedy in medicine, not unless when we administer means of cure in some disease and they do not effect those remedies: then at the end we administer the cautery and it does effect: thus falls the conclusion that the cautery is the last remedy in medicine, not according to the intent which the common people and many quacks understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	Ancient authors said that the cautery with gold is better than the cautery with iron: and they did not say this except for the equality of gold and the sublimity of its substance: and they said that the place does not become pus from the cautery.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	Indeed, this is not absolutely true: for I have already tested it and found that it does not do this in some bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cautery with gold is good and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	Indeed, when you apply the cautery with fire to gold, you do not see clearly when it is ignited according to the quantity you want, because of the rust of the gold: and when it approaches the cold, and if you add ignition to it again, it melts in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Wherefore the artisan falls into occupation: and for that reason a cautery with iron is made for us more swiftly and nearer at hand, from the straightness for the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I have indeed arranged this Chapter on the Cautery according to chapters: and I have ordered them from head to foot: so that he who seeks may obtain what he wishes from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	¶ Concerning the Method of Cauterizing the Coronary Commisurosis.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This cautery treatment concerns the dominance of humidity and cold over the brain: these two causes produce excessive fluid in the eyes and ears, excessive sleep, tooth pain, throat pain, and generally all illnesses caused by cold, such as paralysis, soreness, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar conditions.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is to apply it to the sick: let the head be cleansed first with a purgative medicine for three nights, or four, according to the strength of the patient, and their age, and their habits.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then order him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands in a square posture, so that his hands are placed on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Whereupon therefore your middle finger shall mark that place with the cautery.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then the Olive Cautery with Fire: of which this is the form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it over the marked spot with the ignited instrument, using the descent by which your hand is gradually guided, and you rotate it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then lift your hand quickly, and examine the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that the quantity of the head of alkali or the quantity of zyvherb has already been detected from the bone, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat the action with the instrument itself, or with another one if the first has cooled down: until the bones, which I have told you about, are seen.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take something from the salt, dissolve it in water, and soak the cloth in it. Place it over the spot, and leave it there for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the wet cloth over butter, and leave it over the spot until the burn eschar is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with tetrapharmacum ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have said that the more an injury remains open, the more pus it emits; therefore, it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized down to the bone: and the cauterizing instrument should be held until something of thickness of bone is burned through.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then the burned tissue from the bone is removed, and it is treated thereafter.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that with the cautery one should arrive at the ultimate point until it impresses in the mouth a form like that of a kirate: or an instrument which women place infused with small alphabet: and they believe that vapors from the head are exhaled from this place, and the open wound may be closed over a long period.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be treated until it is consolidated.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But to me these two species of cautery do not appear entirely so except in some persons according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And to remove it, it is better for me with the health of the person.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened by the disruption of its natural continuity: as we have testified in other limbs. And particularly when the head is naturally weak and infirm. Indeed, the first species of cautery is more safe and better for me, and I use it. Therefore, to operate with it is for the health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing the head when there is pain throughout the head.
Caput III.	Head III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When chronic pain occurs throughout the head and persists in the patient, he uses mercury, cochineal, purgatives of the head, oils, and plasters.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized with the cautery we have described, and none of those things are applied to it, then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the patient is strong by nature and not weak, and he finds intense cold: then cauterize with another cautery beneath it lightly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over every horn of the head with a cauterization, and let not the skin pass through, and let the quantity covered from the bone be as we have narrated.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with one cauterization at the back of its head, at a place called vas: and this is the place where the suction cup is put: raise its mature part in this, and do not uncover the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the sick one finds pain due to this, a severe pain different from the pain of other cauterizations of the heads of all.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will say this cauterization in its place: and it must be a cauterization with which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of its head should be cauterized more finely with a finer cauterization, with which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in hemicrania, both with burned medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain and soda occur in part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and the head is evacuated with cleansing medicines, and the remaining treatment is administered as I said in the divisions of diseases, and it does not produce all that result: then cauterization should be performed in two modes: either with burning sharp medicine: or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	The cauterization with sharp burning medicine is as follows: take one tooth of garlic, peel it, and cut its ends from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the place of pain at the time of a broad bloodletting, until a spot beneath the skin is made from which the tooth is taken.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Therefore, introduce it beneath the skin until it is hidden: then tie it with a suitable ligature above it, and release it after fifteen hours, then remove the onion, and let the pulvilus be for two days or three: afterwards place upon it a cloth submerged in butter until the spot produces pus: then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with certain burning medicines, which I wrote about in the twelfth treatise, On Burning Medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Cauterization of it with iron is to be done in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Cauterization with Fire, whose form is this.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called Clavilis: for the shape of its head is like that of a nail, with a round bulge at the top and a small prominence in the middle.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it over the spot and hold your hand there: and turn the iron slowly with velocity, and let the amount that is burned be according to the thickness of the skin, as its half.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand so that the artery below is not burned, and no loss of blood occurs.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then immerse the cloth in salt water, and place it over the spot, and leave it for three days. Then place the cloth in butter, and treat with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this headache with the extremity of the second surgical implement of the Cauterizer.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And beware of incising the artery in this headache, not an old one properly.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in an old headache.
Caput V.	V.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you cure a headache, follow what we have said from the previous cure and what we have said in the divisions of diseases. And if the treatment is not effective: and you see from the disease that what we said with the first cauterization and medicine, or with the cauterization with fire, is not sufficient for him, then you must cauterize with the surgical implement until it whitens after you mark the place of pain with a line whose length is the middle of a finger, or as much as that. And withdraw your hand once, and press it until you incise the artery, and reach up to the mouth.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, you must beware of the continuity of the jaw, which moves during chewing, so that the side or the nerve that moves it is not burned, lest a spasm occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be mindful of the care and precaution regarding the flow of blood in the artery that has been cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For there is fear in its cutting, and especially for one who does not know what he is doing and is neither diligent nor experienced: and he should abandon the operation at first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will excuse myself with the reminder of the regimen for managing the flow of blood that occurs from the artery according to its proper mode and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see from the illness that it does not suffice him this cautery, and you see the body of the sick person bearing the cautery in the middle of the head, as we have narrated, care for the wound until it is healed.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer the cautery which we have mentioned in the chapter of extracting the artery with a cautery having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cautery is better and more effective.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing for pain in the ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear from cold, and it is treated with solutiles and the other treatment as we have said in the division, and the pain does not cease, then use cautery with fire: and this is called Punctum, whose form is as follows.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then prick the area with it after its cautery around the entire circumference of the ear, as it is revolved: or around both sides if the pain is in both ears.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And move the cautery from the root of the ear slightly after marking the places with encaustic: and let the quantity of the cautery be ten pricks in each ear, and as that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then care for the places until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing for Tortura.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	Tortura which is treated with cauteration is not anything other than species that occur from phlegm, as we have said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And the application of cauterization for a species that occurs from drying out and nerve spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this species of torture with fumes from hyssop, and head purges, and gargles, and if the cure does not result from your treatment, then it is necessary to cauterize the patient with three cautery irons: one at the root of the ear, and the second a little below in its proper place, and the third at the conjunction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery on the opposite side of the sick part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not occur except in the part which appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is to apply the cautery to the upper ear extremity beneath the horn of the head slightly: and at another time; whose length shall be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And remove your hand with the cautery until the thickness of half the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a species from the surgical one, the form of which was previously given: yet it should not be slightly more slender than you see: and the knife should be somewhat thicker than necessary.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then treat the place with what preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On the manner of cauterizing in Ancient Apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When ancient apoplexy has prevailed, and you treat it with what we have said, and if your treatment does not result, and the patient does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cautery irons over each horn of his head, and one in the middle of his head, as previously stated, and one at the back of his head, according to what has been mentioned: and the manner of cauterization shall be according to what has been stated.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	And likewise it is cauterized with a Cautery over the mouth of the stomach: and it is more ultimate.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then it is to be cured with what has preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in Oblivion.
Caput IX.	Head IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary to give first great hyssop in drink, and brain purifying pills.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the whole head of the sick person, and apply the plaster described in the treatise on plasters to the back of his head: and apply it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This is indeed the measure of the Cautery: and do that likewise according to the order I said before.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore it is cured by that, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then cauterize three times the back part of his head, which shall descend from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye: and apply between all cauterizations the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then cauterize with what has preceded.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If, however, you wish an addition and the sick person can tolerate that: then cauterize him in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you wish an addition, then cauterize it over the two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then cure it until it is cured: and let the cauterization be oiled according to the form which was given before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the manner of cauterizing in paralysis and softening.
Caput X.	Head X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary to proceed with the purification of the head using hyssop, and with what we have said before.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then scrape the patient's head: thereafter cauterize it with a cauterization in the middle of the head, and with a cauterization over all the horns of the head, and three times over the vertebrae of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If, however, you need to treat the disease of bodily softening in many places, and the patient is weak but the condition is strong: then cauterize it four times over the vertebrae of the back, and the last one thoroughly until the skin burns as much as possible, and raise your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for it until it is healed: and thus the olive cauterization is performed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the manner of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Head XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	The epileptic is not cauterized, except for those whose epilepsy is caused by phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	It is therefore necessary to purify his brain first using hyssop, and with the other treatment we have said in the division: when the patient is severe or tolerates the administration of medicines well.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If, however, it is a child who does not tolerate medicines, then a gargle and chewable brain-purifying substances are administered, along with the improvement of his diet over many days.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head, thereafter cauterize it with one cautery in the middle of the head, according to what has preceded concerning the manner: and with another cautery at the back of him, and over all the horns of his head cauterize.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient is strong and can tolerate it, then cauterize him with the cauteries I said for one with paralysis, and soften the body over the spinal columns of the neck and back. And let the cautery be oily according to the manner that has preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If, however, the patient is a child, then place a fine cautery according to this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the manner of cauterizing for melancholia.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholia is corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize it with the cauteries we have said for one with paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholia is excess decliviens into melancholia, and the body of the patient is wet, then give him to drink what will purify his brain, according to what has preceded in the division. Then shave the patient's head, and make thereafter a tortellam properly made from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head, and let the patient sit with his head held square from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is better with old sheep butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it over fire with a moderate warming that a digit can tolerate when introduced into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle, and let it remain until it cools.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Make him take this remedy once every week until he is cured, with the remainder of his regimen remaining good.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making small punctures in it, and keep your hand with the cautery close at hand; preferably let it smell.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this type of cauterization moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place above it a cloth soaked in butter or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	¶ On the method of cauterizing when water is descending to the eye.
Caput XIII.	XIII. Caput
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the beginning of the water in the eye is revealed to you through the signs I mentioned in the division, then begin and let him take this remedy, which will cleanse his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep him from all humidity, and make him sit in a bath for several days of fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then instruct him to shave his head and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it twice on each temple with two cauterizations, if the beginning of water descending is in both eyes at the same time: or from one side, if the beginning of water is in one eye. And cut all veins and arteries beneath the skin with the cauterization: and let the cauterizations be long in width across the temples: and beware of the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything from it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I pardon with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting them, and caution against the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized in the neck, beneath two bones, with two cauteries brought to a conclusion.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in ancient lacrimal issues.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient and frequent, and are above the veins and arteries which are evident on the exterior of the head, it is verified that this is from excesses of cold and phlegmatic humors: then cauterize with a cautery as I have described at the beginning of the descent of water, in the middle of the head, and with two cauteries over the temples, and with two cauteries in the neck beneath two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you find it necessary to add, then cauterize the same on the entire side of the eye, above the extremity of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in nasal fetor.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat this, along with what we have said in division and not by a complete regimen: then hasten, and give him infirmocochias in the drink for three nights. Then shave his head, and cauterize it with a middle cautery, using an olive oil cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with a cautery called clavilus, using two cauteries above the eyebrows near the hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of the cautery Clauilis.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing in the case of mollification of the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Head XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye becomes softened by illness or humidity: then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, using this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above two eyebrows with a little bit using two cauteries in every part: and let them be spaced from two temporal regions: and the length of all the cautery should be according to the lengths of the eyebrows: and do not end your hand with the cautery at the very ends, but rather according to the amount that is burned on the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cautery according to this manner of lunar cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing the eyelid when hair grows inward and irritates the eye.
Caput XVII.	Head XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery in this case is according to two modes: either with fire: or with a burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In the cautery with fire, first instruct the patient to remove his own hairs, if they are of those that naturally clean themselves, until they grow out and become equal.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If they irritate him at their point of growth, then bind his eyes with swabs so that they do not move until they grow out.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When therefore they are born and equated, then place the head of the sick man in your bosom: then mark over the eyelids of his eyes with a cauterizing agent, the mark that is according to the figure of the leaf of myrtle: and let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a soaked cloth in albumen of egg: or in psyllium mucilage over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then cauterize with a burner, whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize according to the figure you marked gradually in succession many times, until the skin surface is burned, which is like the figure of a myrtle leaf, completely visible.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of health of your work is: that if you see the eyelid of the eye now contract, and hairs rise near the puncture of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Lift then your hand: and release it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place over it a cloth with butter until the scab is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then attend to it with ointment until it heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any of the hairs return within an hour and the eyelid softens: then iterate the cauterization over that place, as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If the hairs are on the lower lid: then cauterize it until they rise to their natural place, and equalize so that the hairs do not irritate the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	¶ Method of cauterizing with burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is that you instruct the sick person to let his hair grow until it is prolonged and equalled.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from paper the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from known soap and unabsorbed ash of each one a weight of an ounce or nearly that: then rub these together well and make them quickly, so that they do not cool.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then spread it out on the paper you made as the shape of a myrtle leaf, and place it over the eyelid(s) of one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a cloth soaked in white of egg: and the sick person's head be near your body.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your index finger on the medicine, and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you move it whenever the sick person feels the bite of the medicine: for he finds its bite like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore the sick person continues to feel the bite of the medicine, then remove the medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When therefore the bite has ceased, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then, if you see the eyelid lift, as it does with contraction from fire or incision, it is well: and if not, then apply the medicine again to the same place, where the medicine does not mark or damage, until your operation equals and constricts the eye.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then apply over it a mixture of cotum and butter until the burned skin is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with diaphinicon ointment or another, until it is cured.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And you must beware during the operation to use the final safeguard, so that nothing from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelid softens after a few days and something from the hair fights against it in the eye, then apply the medicine to that place which softens from the eyelid properly, just as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is cured.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that human eyes vary in size and shape.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to this, consider it: and the way of righteousness is not hidden from him who has a study in this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	¶ Concerning the method of cauterizing in lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Head XXI.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula, as we have said in the divisions of diseases, and your treatment is not effective: then, you must cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the patient to place his head in your lap, and hold his head with a servant between your hands in such a way that it is not moved nor shaken with his body.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply infused cotum in a milky solution or in a psyllium mucilage to his eye: then use a cauterization instrument, the form of which is as follows.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be a concave, as the form of an eagle's feather from one end, with which the cautery is made: and if you wish it to penetrate to the other end, and if you wish it to go up thus try.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum valde.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	Si ergo peruenis in principium Cauterii tuus usque ad os, erit bene.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illi: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Deinde pone cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccativo, donec sanetur.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosivam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod venit in capitulo suo.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another mode of cautery fistula, which some of the first mentioned.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Intend to the place of the fistula, and cut it: then place in the same fissure caumhan subtle, that is, a fine cannula, whose form is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it a quantity of a drachm from melted lead, and hold your hand with a good Cannula for retention, and let the patient not move at all, so that the melted lead does not run or reach his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And you should place on the patient's eye a cloth soaked in white wine, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For the lead burns the place of the fistula and heals it with a marvelous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	For if the fistula is healed, together with what we have said from the cautery and its treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer a nostril opening, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what it will come to its proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	¶ Concerning the mode of cautery in fissures of the Lips.
Caput XX.	Head XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Fissures of the lip, which they call pili, often occur and are especially prevalent in children's lips.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you treat these fissures, as we have said in the division of ailments, and if the treatment is not sufficient, then prepare a small cautery with fire, according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And its concavity according to the subtlety of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the ignited instrument quickly into the fissures, until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with a cerate until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	¶ Concerning the method of cautery in oral fistulas.
Caput XXI.	Head XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an apostema occurs at the root of the tooth, in the palate, or at the roots of the teeth: it then produces pus and breaks open. Afterwards, it heals over, but the pus reappears and a fistula forms. Then treat the fistula itself, and if no cure is见效，我需要进一步调整方案。请稍等，我将重新评估并提供一个更有效的解决方案。
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the ignited instrument into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand there until the heated iron reaches the depth and deepest part of it. Do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then treat it afterwards, using the method we have described until it is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the pus is removed and it heals, that will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to discover the location and remove the source of corruption according to what appears at its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	¶ Concerning the method of cautery for softened gums and teeth.
Caput XXII.	Head XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gums become softened due to humidity, and the teeth are moved, and you treat it with medicines without cautery: then place the sick person's head in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then the fire brand, whose form will come after this, so that you place the Cannula over the tooth: and thrust in the ignited Cauterium quickly: and hold your hand somewhat, until the patient feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And raise your hand: then iterate the Cauterium several times, according to your desire.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient fill his mouth with salt water, and hold it for a while: then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth is moved and made firm, the gums softened and tightened, and the corrupted moisture dried up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing for tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	Head XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the tooth pain is due to cold, either the cold itself is present, or a worm, and no remedy with medicines is effective: then the Cauterium on the tooth is according to two modes: either the Cauterium with butter: or the Cauterium with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The Cauterium with butter is as follows: take fresh butter and boil it in a iron dish or a vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take cotton and wrap it around the end of the probe.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse it in the boiled butter: and place it quickly over the painful tooth, and hold it until it cools down: then iterate it several times, until the power of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, immerse cotton or wool in cold butter, and place it over the painful tooth: then place a heated iron on top of it until the heat reaches the deep cavity of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	Cauterization of it with fire is done, so that you may direct yourself to the air tube, or the iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And there be something of thickness in its body, so that the sharpness of the fire may not reach the sick person's mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then apply the cautery heated by fire: place it over the tooth: and hold your hand there until the cautery cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be relieved either on the same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And the patient should fill his mouth with good yarn and hold it for one hour; then spit out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with any extremity as is possible: and this is the form of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in Strophuli.
Caput XXIIII.	Head XXIV.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When Strophuli are caused by phlegm and cold humors, and are not responsive to medical treatments for digestion, and you wish to quickly promote digestion, then apply a concave cautery heated by fire, whose form is as follows.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, so that smoke escapes from the other end of the cautery: and place the heated one over the abscess once, and a second time if necessary, until it reaches the depth of the abscess.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the abscess is small: then apply a cautery according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then let it alone for three days, and apply a wet dressing infused in butter until what the fire burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with tooth ointment until the form of the tube is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	¶ Regarding the method of cauterizing in hoarseness and constriction of breathing.
Caput XXV.	Head XXV.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When the humours overcome the pulmonary tube, and especially when this is accompanied by a cold constitutional condition, then it is necessary to evacuate the patient with purgative medicines at first.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it on the nocard at the root of the throat at the depressed spot. And beware, do not apply the cautery to the throat or the skin unless there is something to indicate it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another cautery at the join of the neck at the last vertebra, extending it: and let the cautery be pointed iron according to the size previously mentioned.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what has been mentioned before until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	¶ Regarding the method of cauterizing in diseases of the lung and cough.
Caput XXVI.	Head XXVI.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.
