Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	Therefore, when this occurs to someone, hasten with your hand to the opening of the artery, and place your index finger over it: and press it greatly until the blood is obstructed beneath your finger and nothing escapes from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then place some small olive oil cautery sticks into fire and many more: and blow upon them until they are ignited greatly.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one of them, whether small or large, according to the wound and place where the artery is disrupted, and place the cautery upon the vein itself, after which you remove your finger quickly: and hold the cautery until the blood is shed.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	And if the blood is expelled when you lift your finger from the aperture of the artery and you extinguish the cautery, then take another cautery quickly, from those that are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore, do not cease to do this with one after another until the blood is shed.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And beware that you do not burn the nerve there, and let no other evil happen to the weak patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from the artery, it is not possible to cauterize it: especially when the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it has not yet been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, the extremities thereof are drawn together, and the blood is shed.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it may be tied off with a strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or medicines with properties to stop the bleeding may be applied upon it, and it should be compressed with a suitable ligature.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever performs amputation with a ligature, and stricture with cloth, or the placement of combustion or similar items, does not altogether deprive him, unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If, however, such a thing happens to someone, and there is no physician nor medicine at hand: then begin with the placement of the index finger over the orifice of the vein itself, as we have narrated, and by strongly constriction thereof until the blood is obsessed from the upper part of the wound and over the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger not be removed, with cold water of vehement frost always applied from above until the blood congeals and thickens and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile, consider what he needs from cauterization or from medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	¶ End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Libre Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	¶ Concerning Incision, Puncture, and Phlebotomy in Wounds, and Similar Conditions.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We Have Already Spoken in Chapter One of Every Illness in Which Cauterization and Combustible Medicine Are Appropriate, and the Opportunities for Their Use, as Well as the Causes and Instruments and Forms of Such Cauterizations.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed there the chapters from the head to the foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter along the same path: that the sought remedy be made clear to those who seek it.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin, my son, you must learn what is here from the fear that is in Chapter One concerning cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for this reason, there should be a greater caution in it, because in the operation which is in this chapter, evacuation with blood happens multitudes of times, with which life stands at the opening of the vein, or incision over an apostema, or opening of the exit, or cure of the wound, or extraction of the arrow, or incision over a stone, and such like: from all of these there arises trembling, and fear, and death falls upon many of them.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I advise you that hesitation may fall upon you, for sometimes such men with their conditions fall into this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For from these are those who become angry with their illness, and death is easy for them: because of the vehemence with which they find themselves in their illness and the length of their wickedness.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when the illness is from fear, which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And from these are those who give you their blessing and enrich you with it, hoping for your health, and their illness is harmful.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, it is not fitting to agree with him who comes to you from such a condition.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be greater than your cupidity and greed.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume on anything from that, unless after certain knowledge, which is verified among you by the successful succession to what follows.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use in the cure of all your sick, the prognosis and indication for what is conducive to their health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	In that there is aid for you in acquiring fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	Let God inspire you, my children, your understanding, and may He not take away from you direction and inspiration: for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I have indeed arranged this Chapter by distinguishing it into sections, according to how it proceeded in the Chapter on Cauterization, from the neck down to the feet: so that you may easily find what you wish from it and where you need it.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	¶ Concerning the Treatment of Water That Aggregates in Children's Heads.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this illness often occurs in children after birth: or when the midwife presses the child's head without delicacy.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And it also occurs sometimes from a hidden cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I have indeed not seen this illness in anyone other than children: and death came to every one of them whom I saw. Therefore, it seemed to me advisable to omit surgery in such cases.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I have indeed seen among them a child whose head was filled with water, and the head enlarged every day until it could no longer sit upright due to the size of its head. And the moisture increased until the child died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture aggregates either between the skin and the skull or under the bone at the base of the skull.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation, if the moisture is between the skin and the skull and the abscess is small, then you should make a single fissure in the middle of the head. The length of the fissure should be about two nodes until the moisture runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the form of the spatula.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the humidity is more increased, and the abscess is larger, then make these two fissures, according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the humidity is beneath the bone, and its sign is that you see the openings of the roots of the teeth widely from every part: and water is depressed when you compress it with your hand towards the interior, and you do not conceal it from yourself: then you must make three fissures in the middle of the jaw according to this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, extract all the humidity.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then close the fissures with cloths and compresses.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then dress it with a mixture of wine and oil for five days.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then release the bandage, and care for the wound with dressings and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not cease to bind the head with equal tightness.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And give the patient food that is dry and of little moisture until the limb is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And the method of the incision is different, so consider where the size of the abscess and the collection of water are apparent.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes there is more at the back of the head, or at the front, or on the right side, or on the left side.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore ascend with the incision where you see the abscess and collection of water, and cut into it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, lest you pierce an artery, and a flow of blood occur, and the sick person die from that flow with evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	¶ On Incising Arteries Located After the Ears.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When catarrhs affect one's eyes or chest, and the condition worsens despite no improvement with medical treatment: then more effective treatment is to incise these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when you wish to incise them, the patient should shave his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the area with a rough cloth to make the arteries visible.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the patient should tie his neck with any cloth.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then observe where the vein pulses.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the locations of both are areas depressed below the ears: and it is rarely concealed, except in some individuals.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark the areas with cauterization on both sides: and incise both with a sharp blade on each side, extending the incision to the base of the skull: and let this be done across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert the sharp blade under the artery, and incise it upwards with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be about two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is incised, blood issues forth with the pulsatile flow, rising to the interior by a frequent leap.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If the artery does not appear by touch, then it is necessary to measure from the ear a distance of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with cauterization, and cut until the mouth.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which should be drawn from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps you will draw more or less.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	Do this according to the quantity which appears to you from the condition of the patient and the fullness of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider [the wound].
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if something remains to the mouth, then cut it out, so that a hot abscess does not occur: then suture the wound with needles made of linen thread.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then attend to it with ointment until it is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	¶ Concerning the extraction of arteries, which are in tumors.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a person suffers from old headache, or acute catarrh due to acrid humidities, and the heat of the season in the limbs, or old soda, violent and similar to these: and is treated with methods of medical cure, but does not benefit from it; then we have found that the extraction of arteries from the tumors, or cauterization of them, as we have described, is effective.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in extracting them is that the patient shaves the hair that is on the tumor, and directs attention to the artery appearing on the tumor.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	That artery is shown to you by the patient's pulse, and rarely does it become hidden unless in a few individuals or due to cold fainting.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If this is concealed from you, then the sick person should wrap his head with any of his own cloth; then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or let vapors arise from water hot, until it is apparent to you clearly.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the spatumile, which I formed a moment ago.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape the skin with it easily until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then投射一个钩子进去，向外拉到上方，直到你将其从皮肤中拉出，并使其从其下方的包层中完全出来。
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the artery is fine, then envelop it with the hook's tip.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from that part according to the quantity by which its extremities are drawn out and contracted, so that no blood flow occurs.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut and not severed, the blood will not rise completely.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then evacuate six inches of blood, until three inches remain.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large, then you must tie it in two places with a double, strong silk thread or with cords of alhohod, so that decay does not reach it before the wound heals, and no blood flow occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut the excess tissue between the two ties.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do that at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery until the extremities thereof, using a surgical cautery: until its edges are burned, and it will hold its place in the work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better to do the work, unless the patient has a fever or a heated complexion.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Since the cautery is from those things that heal to end humidities.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better to use healing.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of the arteries to fill the place with old cloth: and let them be placed upon it finely made pledgets.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the wound is cleansed with dry medicines that cause flesh to grow, and with dressings, until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	And if meanwhile, while operating, a blood flow from the artery occurs, then hurry to cut it off with a cautery, or to fill the place with ghee and bind tightly until the blood is stopped.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	And if nothing of those is present with you, then place your finger on the spot until the blood congeals.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And apply a compress to the place with water of violent coldness until the sharpness subsides, and bind it as necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And because it is lighter and easier in the extraction of the artery, you should cauterize the vein with this cautery having two knives: and let the sharpness of the two knives be like alum.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	Yet they have much less sharpness than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Since they are acute, like two knives, he applies cold to both: and do not pierce the flesh with velocity.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	When therefore there is a certain thickness in them, heat of fire is applied to them, and the flesh is cut quickly: since this must be done better for every work, more moderately, and more easily.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between the two knives be the thickness of a finger, after you mark two places with cauterization: and extinguish both fires greatly, until they reach the surface, and incise the vein in two places: so that what is between its extremities may elongate.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they are not completely consolidated with this cauterization.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cauterization.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	¶ On the care of acute and frequent flow of tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Head IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When the tears are frequent, and the flow is from veins on the exterior of the skull above the head: and medicine with medicines does not bring relief to them, you will see the face of the sick person already reddening, and they feel a crawling sensation on their forehead, as if from ants: and their eyes are weakened, moist, so that even the hairs on them are corroded by moisture: and his eyelids are heated due to the acuteness of the tears: then the ancients required this operation for their treatment, and named it the cure with the Knife.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And you should instruct the sick person to shave the hair on their forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three cuts in the forehead at equal distances according to the length of the forehead: and let the length of the cut be about two fingers, and one cut shall be equidistant from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second slightly according to the length of the lower arm, and the third on the other side: and beware of cutting the arteries which are on both sides: and stretch your hand from the continuity of the two jaws, and let the space of all the cuts be that of three fingers joined together: and prepare for you a fragment of sponge or many dried cloths with which to dry the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert the blades of two pointed forceps, whose subsequent form is described next.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is on the side of the temple, to the second incision: and strip off with it the entire skin which is between the two incisions, together with the scab, which is over the mouth.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do the same from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract these forceps, and insert into the first incision again another instrument, which is called the sharp scalpel, gently from one side, not sharply from the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side towards the flesh attached with skin, and its gentle side towards the mouth. Push it until it reaches the middle cut: and cut with it all the vessels that descend from the head to the eyes, except where the incision is continued down to what appears from the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do the same from the middle cut to the other cut.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after the quantity of blood has run out, express the places from the clots of coagulated blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place lime from old plaster in every fissure, and place above them wicks soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that no hot abscess occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day, release the ligature, and administer a strong infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with basilicon ointment and other ointments used for wounds until it is cured.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	¶ Concerning the treatment of acute tears and catarrhs affecting the eyes from internal head conditions.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When acute, severe, and frequent catarrhs occur to someone, you will see their eyes weakened, small, and already their appearance is weakened. The eyelids are ulcerated, and hair falls from them. There is a sharp pain in the depths of the head, painful and accompanied by sneezing. Then take from these conditions what those materials and catarrhs do not come from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the better treatment for this is as follows.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And you should order the patient to shave their forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make one incision in the middle of the forehead, or slightly wide on the other side, and begin with the incision from the left temple to the right temple. The cut should go down to the mouth. Extend your hand from the temporal bones, which move during chewing, until the mouth is exposed. Then dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two labia of the fissure with old cotta, or with linen strips.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then suture from above with pulvillae: and soak the pulvillae in wine and oil, so that no hot abscess occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you solve this, and see that the hot abscess is diminishing: then it is necessary to foment the wound until flesh begins to grow there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then care for it with an excisive regimen that promotes the growth of flesh: as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony, and prepare a paste from them, and this should be applied to the growth of flesh in such wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	¶ Concerning the care of what falls into the Ear.
Caput VI.	Head VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	All that falls into the ear is of one of four species: either a mineral stone, or similar to a stone, as iron and glass: or it is from a plant, as chickpea and bean: or it is a fluid substance, as water and vinegar and the like: or some animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone or genus of stone that does not added to or grow in the ear falls into the ear, expose the ear to heat: if therefore you see the stone, then drop something from violet oil or camphor into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer the extraction of it, and make the patient sneeze when you insert it, and plug the nostrils at the approach of sneezing. After you place fragments of cloth or wool around the ear, and extend the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For he often emerges with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If he does not emerge, then administer his extraction with Gosti's fine forceps: the form of which is as follows.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If he emerges with the forceps, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer his extraction with a blind hook of fine single folding.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	And if he does not emerge through that, then make a tube of bronze, and introduce the end of the tube into the ear opening much, and powder which is in the circumference of the tube with softened caera and oil, so that there be no passage except through the tube: then extract it with your strong suction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For he often emerges with what we have described.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If he does not emerge this way, then take from the helical part, or from the worm, that is, prepared gluten with which birds are caught, a small amount: and place it at the end of the radius after you wrap something over it properly positioned. Then introduce it into the ear opening with ease, after you have dried the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If he does not emerge with all that we have described, then hasten to cut before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the measure of the incision is to use phlebotomy on the weak first in the cephalic vein: and extract from him blood according to the measure of its strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then seat the patient between your hands, and turn his ear upwards, and make a small incision at the root of the ear near its fat in a depressed spot: let the incision be lunar-shaped until you reach the stone; then extract it along with what is possible for you with the instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then use the wound from your time with speed, and care it until it is healed.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If it is a falling object into the ear from one grain, which grows and swells: then administer its extraction.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not yield to you for extraction, then take a thin spatula fine, according to this form.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the excision of that species from the grains which fall into the ear, and do not perform this when you think that grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear until you place many fragments thereof: then extract them with forceps, or with a fine probe, or with suction, as we have said, for the extraction of it should be made easier.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	In water which enters the ear, the patient should use a sneeze when first placed there: and now his ear is filled with some amount of old fluid: and he lies on the side of the ear where the water is.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If it therefore exits through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of a finger, thin and soft, and heat them slightly with fire, and the patient should insert one from them into the opening of his ear: and let one fall from that side, and strike it with another stone on the stone which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore, let him continue doing this with the stone and stone until all the water exits.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now the water exits such that you may take one feather or one reed, and insert one end of it into the ear: and ignite the other end with fire until most of it burns.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then iterate with another ligature, and do this many times until all the water has emerged: and extract it with the cannula as previously stated on the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction of an animal entering it, if it is of a small body, such as a louse, and similar, take care to extract it as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of a large body, which is apparent by sense: then administer its extraction with forceps and hooks: and this is easier than all that is held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	In the extraction of a worm generated in the ear, when you treat it with what we said in the division and in the discussion of distillations, and your treatment does not confer relief: then you should examine the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something from the worms is apparent there, then extract it with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If however nothing is apparent there, then take a cannula, the form of which is narrow at the bottom and broad at the top: and introduce the fine end into the ear according to the quantity that the sick person can tolerate: then suck with that strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times until all the worms have emerged.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If however they do not obey you and exit, then surround the cannula with a probe, as I said on the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not emerge with what we have said: then administer the distillations which the ancients used for the destruction of worms, and you will find this in the discussion of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your effusion which you pour forth of oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, make it from silver or copper, drawn out at the bottom, with a small hole at the bottom and a larger one at the top.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let it be such that what is in the concavity of the cannula is made of air unevenly.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a ray, and wrap its extremity with cotton in a suitable winding: then project oil, or juice, or what you wish from these medicines into the cannula: and let it be in the ear: then insert the ray with cotton above, and express it with your hand applying moderate compression until the oil is pushed into the concavity of the ear, and the patient feels it internally: and that which is poured into the ear may now be warmed slightly with fire: and beware lest what distills into it be very cold: for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	¶ Concerning the care of the accident of opillation of the Ear.
Caput VII.	Head VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes infants emerge from their mothers' wombs unperforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it has also happened to some people that opillation occurs in the meatus of the ear due to a wound or flesh arising from there.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this opillation sometimes occurs in the deep meatus of the ear, which does not result from usage: and it also happens to the outer part of the meatus to a slight degree, and is caused by such usage.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which happens deep within the Ear, and which is not grasped by sight, is in many dispositions difficult of cure.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which follows concerning the use of the Ear, you should place the affected Ear in the sun and look into it. Then, if you see an appearance of cleaning, open it with a slender spatule, the form of which is as follows: its end has a certain small breadth, and a part of it is sharp, and the rest of the spatule has two gentle sides: so that it does not damage the Ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore the cleaning is born of flesh in the meatus of the Ear, then hold it with a slender hook, and cut it with vehement facility until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the cleaning is deep within the Ear: then take a slender, gentle spatule, and warm it slightly with fire. Then put it into the meatus of the Ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If therefore you perceive cleaning with that which the patient experiences with great heaviness of hearing, attempt to open it with facility: and beware, lest you injure the nerves of the Ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place a wick in the Ear according to the width of the opening, which you have wrapped in Egyptian ointment. Do this for a few days until you are secure about the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take a wick, and steep it in rosewater, and powder it with ground zegi, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see the Ear already suppurating: then you should extract the wick, and let it come into contact with another wick wrapped in cerate made with rose oil, until the hot suppuration is settled. Then care for it until it is completely cured.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If however there occurs a flow of blood: then immerse the sponge or cloth in cold water, and place it upon it the ear: and continue with the rest of the treatment which cuts off the flow of blood as described in the treatise on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Of the care of Altheli palpebras.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These Altheli that affect the eyelids sometimes are wet, and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore, you must hold them with forceps: or with a clamp, and cut them away from their roots with forceps.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place powdered zinc above the affected areas.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If however blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a thin lens-shaped cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And cauterizing them is better after incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For they often return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	Of the care of Granuloma of the eyelids.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Often something occurs on the eyelids that is similar to Granuloma in its strength and hardness, and for this reason it is called Granuloma: and it is an aggregation of coarse moisture on the upper eyelid and lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Therefore, the operation on them is that you should consider then if there is a growing swelling appearing from the eyelid, and move about to every part, and its nature is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Find therefore above it a fissure through the width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape it from every part with facility until it exits.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a hook, and cut it out.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If, however, the excision thereof is not prepared for you, so that you must penetrate the eyelid with a slight incision, then it harms the patient in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the fissure is large, then unite it with a suture and care for it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For ointment restores it and causes it to heal.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the swelling has declined toward the inner ear surface, then invert the eyelid and suspend the swelling with a hook. Additionally, you will need to make an incision and press it from every part.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	If the eyelid is extended by an incision, it does no harm to anything.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision with the swelling, using brine water, and care for the area with what causes healing until the patient is cured.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	¶ On the care of Axirnath eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is the fat that generates in the tunics of the upper eyelids: and it indeed happens frequently to children. And this burdens their eyes, and causes them morning catarrhs, and they cannot look at the sun's light because the tears hurry to them. Therefore, you will see them always lying on their faces, and sleeping upon them, and their eyelids beneath the eyebrows are moist, which have now been covered by inflammation: and the prominence of Axirnath is visible to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of its operation is, that the patient places his head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth, and prepare a lint on it, and make from that lint a circle according to the quantity that contains the Axirnath from all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place it over the affected area, and press it with your fingers from all sides, so that the Axirnath collects in the center of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then make incisions in the middle of that humidity with a spatula gently, and let the incisions be narrow, not as wide as those made in phlebotomy deep within.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or you must incise the skin completely until you reach the Axirnath, for in many dispositions, the Axirnath proceeds from the incision according to the shape of a white fat fruit.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Therefore, extract it with the linen you saturated between your fingers: and you turn your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed. Be careful not to add to the incision so that you do not reach the eye with the spatula and injure it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If, however, Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the fissure, you shall add a little force to the fissure with facility until Axirnath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse cloths in vinegar and water, and place them over the area, and bind it with wicks.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are some who grind salt and put it into the cavity of the fissure, so that what remained from that humidity may liquefy.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If, however, a hot abscess occurs in the area, then care for it with soothing plasters until it is healed.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	¶ Concerning the method of Ataxmir for the eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes softened, from which it happens that it wrinkles as it should not.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When additional hairs appear on the eyelids beyond their natural course and thicken, then these are harmful to the eye and cause ailments such as frequent tears, softening of the eyelids, and conjunctivitis, until they lead to the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And Ataxmir for the eye is treated according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, as prescribed in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Ataxmir is treated by incision and suturing.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by catheterization, as I shall say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You must place the head of the sick person in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If therefore it turns, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if it does not turn: insert a needle into that part where the thread is from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle with the thread penetrate upwards, and let it be close to the hairs, that is, close to the edge of the eyelid, where the hairs grow: and pull the thread up with the eyelid, and turn it with a pin.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then incise in the inner part of the eyelid under the hairs with a spatillum (spoon-shaped instrument) extending from the larger lacrimal gland to the smaller lacrimal gland.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then extract the thread, and place a small woolen plug under the eyelid, made from cotton or cloth. Then mark the eyelid with encaustic wax, which should be in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that the figure be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid, since this varies among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For some need for a considerable amount to be incised from the eyelid, according to the quantity that is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then, using a spatillum, incise over the two lines you marked, starting from the larger lacrimal gland to the smaller lacrimal gland, and let the incision be one continuous slit near the natural hairs, as wide as the thickness of a radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of the two angular skins.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape away the entire layer.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then缝合两唇，用细羊肠线和针：并擦去血液，并使多余的线从双眼上方的部分黏合，如有必要可加入其他一些东西；如果不需要，也不必在意。
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then remove the stitches and thread for three days or four: afterwards care for it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without stitches and care for it along with what dries and tightens it.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid will rise above the sealing of the wound and its缝合：但以后会更好。
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of caring for the wound was taught by the ancients to Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	Yet there is vigilance for the sick person, and it is from good practice, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method is used by Ataxmir as well: and it is to make a mark on the eyelid in the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we have described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then lift the eyelid with three separate or joined hooks, according to the following shape, then cut away what is多余的，按照这个形状，切口要均匀。
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If, however, it is not possible for you to hold the hook and make it equal: then take a needle with thread and insert it into the middle of the shape. Insert another thread near the larger lacrimal, and another thread near the smaller lacrimal: and gather the threads between your fingers with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then elevate your hand with equal elevation: and elevate the skin over which a mark is made cut, as we have narrated.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the two lips of the wound with a suture: and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If however an apostema occurs at your incision or fissure: apply that apostema with a cautery, and with similar things, from soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens that the eyelids even turn such that their hairs invert.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore, you should use what we have said regarding the incision; but a suture is more artificial for this.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	¶ Concerning the care of Ataxmir with reeds.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And when you have turned the eyelid and split the fissure within, as we have narrated.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two reeds or two thin pieces of wood, whose length be according to the length of the eyelid, and their width be narrower than that of a spatula: and you have now incised at the extremities on both sides from each side where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then join both with a细线超出了眼睛睑的部分，並從兩個方向緊繃兩根葦杆，用力結紮，然後幾天後解除。
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin tightened will die, blacken, and putrefy, until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If therefore it is delayed, then cut it off with forceps.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for her until she is healed.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it has consolidated, elevate the eyelid: and the hairs do not pierce.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of two canulas, which you should make according to this figure and quantity in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	For the removal of piercing hairs from the eye using a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter Twelve.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation is as follows: take a fine needle, and insert a thread of fine silk into it.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then tie its ends together, and make knots with fine knots on both sides: let the length of the threads be one hand's breadth.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then place another fine thread beneath it briefly, and make knots at its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then the patient should place his head in your lap, and it should be near the sun to demonstrate the operation: for it is a delicate or small operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with the thread into the root of the eyelid, and make it quickly penetrate the eyelid, until you pull out the natural hair from above.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the hair until it is above the thread: and insert that hair into the thread: if there is one, or two, or three hairs, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand with it until the hair comes out with the thread from the eyelid along with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If however the axinotati is pulled and a hair does not come out with it: pull the axinotati downward, using the thread which you have prepared in it, until the axinotati comes out of the upper opening, and you see it with your eyes: then you pull the axinotati and the thread: and withdraw both, and close the eye: and let it remain closed for two or three days, until the hair adheres to its place, and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either associate it with a longer hair from natural hairs and lift it with it, or let it alone until it lengthens after some time, and then lift it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	Of the care of Alxatrati which occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this Alxatratis occurs in the eye, it is named Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this Alxatrati is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Therefore, it is accidental from the consolidation of a wound, or a section, or a cauterization, and similar conditions.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of treatment is to find that consolidation, to separate its edges, and to place something moderate between them from linen, and to bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not appropriate to use things that dry and constrict in its treatment. For if you do this, the Alxatrati will return worse than before: rather, use things that soften, such as hay, wormwood, a compress in water in which althea has been boiled, flax seed, and dyactive ointment melted with some oil: wrap something moderate around it and treat it accordingly.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And thy treasury of care is that thou strive with every ingenuity lest it consolidate according to the form which was first.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we have said is nothing but a correction of Alxatrati, lest the form return to that which it was entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	¶ Of the care of Alxatrati which is done in the lower eyelid, and it is a wrinkling or contracting upwards to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This operation which is done below is truly called Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And it is accidental, arising from a wound, or crack, or cauterization, and similar conditions.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way of the operation is this: take a needle with a double thread, and insert it into the flesh, and make it penetrate from the left lacrimal gland to the right lacrimal gland until the thread reaches the two extremities of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh upwards with the needle, and cut it with a broad spatula.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns as it should, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if it does not return, take a needle, and place it in the crack, and turn with it the eyelid. And make two cracks on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two cracks be from the two corners of the incision until they meet and form an angle: when they are aggregated, this is their shape, and it is the letter lambda in Greek.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh in the quantity which is the acute side below, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separated parts: sew them with a wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we have said about softening medicines and their appropriateness until they are cured.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if Alxatrati occurs from a crack, and suture, or cauterization: then you must find the flat crack beneath the eyelashes, even according to what has preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with appropriate material, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the summary of treating Alxatrati when it is above or below is that the operation should be performed according to how it is prepared from the form of Alxatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	That itself is of many varied forms: and the skilled artisan prepares the incision with whatever means are possible until it returns to or approaches the natural form, and the patient himself, according to what is suitable for him from the operation and instruments in various disposals.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	¶ Concerning the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva or cornea.
Caput XV.	Head XI.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this consolidation occurs in many people, such that the upper eyelid fuses with the white of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, you must insert the tip of a probe under the eyelid and lift it upwards: or extend it with a forceps. Then incise the adhesion with a sharp spatula, which should not be as锐利 as the edge of a spatula, but slightly obtuse: so that the patient is not disturbed during the operation, and the spatula can be removed without injuring the eye with its sharpness: and your incision should almost tear away the adhesion with ease until when the eyelid returns to its natural form and the entire adhesion is cured.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye, wash it out with water: or distill into it through a sieve made from zinc dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate the eyelid from the eye with a linen wick: and place over the eye wool soaked in white vitreous matter: and on the third day use the sieve, and with solids, until it is cured.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	¶ Incision of the nail and protrusion of the tear gland flesh.
Caput XVI.	Head XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the nail is according to two modes.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is nerveous: and it is similar to a hard, fine sieve.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nerveous, similar to white moisture frozen: which when it touches iron, or you try to grasp it with a hook, it breaks off and the hook does not stick in it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin until the tear duct becomes inflamed, gradually until it covers the visible surface and obstructs vision and eye movement.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operation in incising it is: that the patient place his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then collect the nail using a hook of few doublings and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert a strand of hair from horse, cow, or goat hair into it. Let the thread be strong, and slightly double the end of the needle, and fix it in the middle of the nail: and penetrate it with the needle, and tie the nail with the thread, and extend it upwards: and peel off with the hair on the side of the nail that follows the pupil, as if you weave it with the hair until its very tip.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remainder at the root of the lacrimal gland with a thin spatula or with small forceps: and remove the natural lacrimal flesh, so that there does not occur an incessant flow of tears from this incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And at times the horn is extended with a single hook: or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it is scraped with a gentle spatula, the form of which is as follows.
