Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then release the ligature on the patient, and place your finger on the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place the cloth and ligatures over it, and ligate it from above with a strong constriction. Release it until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And the recall of these, and their cutting, and their extraction have already been discussed at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Of phlebotomy of the frontal vein after phlebotomy of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	Indeed, the ligature of the phlebotomy of the frontal vein is after phlebotomy of the head, for ancient diseases of the face: and for hemigraine, and erythrasma: and for foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is, as I shall tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The sick person compresses his neck with a string until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument called Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Of which this is the form.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place a prominent point at the top of the Fossorium over the vein, and strike it with a plectrum or some other object in that manner, and let the blood flow according to the amount you desire.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then release the perforation of the sick person, and bind it tightly until it is healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it is opened with a broad phlebotomy.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	Indeed, it is not appropriate, however, to be a sharp-ended phlebotomy, as are the other phlebotomies, but rather a broad-ended one.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And perform the phlebotomy according to the displacement: for the opening is nearby, and perhaps the phlebotomy will be broken when it is fine.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of phlebotomy of the Veins in the Two Lacrimal Areas.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The ligature of the two Veins which are in the two Lacrimal bones of the eyes, is for the eye from scabies and russet taint: and it infects the eye, and diseases of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that the sick person tightens his neck with a woody rod.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then phlebotomize them: and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the phlebotomy be made across the length somewhat, using a small phlebotome that is a little broad, for there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	For if the phlebotome is thin at the tip, it may perhaps break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let it run with the blood as much as you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place cloths over them, and tighten them for one night, and release them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	¶ Concerning the phlebotomy of the Nasal Veins.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The phlebotomy of the Nasal Veins is applied to acute fever, sore throat, and severe diseases of the face, such as hemigraine and russet taint that occurs on the face: particularly when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that the sick person tightens his neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold his nose with your left hand, and take a thin, long phlebotome: and insert it in the middle of his nose, between what distinguishes the nostrils according to their straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the veins do not appear to the sense there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And you must use your last hand with the phlebotome slightly: and make the blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then ligate it on the same night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is restored quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	¶ Concerning the Phlebotomy of Veins according to Guidehi.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The efficacy of Guidehi's phlebotomy is for the constriction of shortness of breath, and the onset of leprosy, and melancholic illnesses, and impetigo and malignant sores, and those corroding, that is, eruptive diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that the sick person be tied under both sides at the neck with a ligature: and let the craftsman stand over the head of the sick person, and let the sick person sit on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then make the phlebotomy broad along the vein slightly.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw from the vein a measured quantity of blood, or according to what you see is necessary for that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then undo the ligature, and tie the two veins with a medium tightness: so that the sick person does not become suffocated.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let her remain thus until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound is healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Of Phlebotomy of Veins Al Gebir.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	Veins, however, are useful for phlebotomy because they contribute to febrile conditions in the mouth, and corruption of the gums: and bad sores: and fissures of the lips, and bad sores, even those that are in the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of these veins for phlebotomy is that you make the sick person sit before you: and press his neck with a cloth.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then roll back his lip and look at two veins: of which one is on the right lip, and the second on the left: and the demonstration of both is by the blackness of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true: for around them are small veins, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore cut both with an incision slanting in.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If there is any doubt about you, and you do not know which one it is: then direct your incision to the larger one, and make that one more apparent.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly do for the two veins in the upper lip: and indeed the custom directs most often to that: and cut the two veins which are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Of Phlebotomy of Veins Under the Tongue after Cranial Phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	Of the Veins under the Tongue, for phlebotomy: it is that phlebotomy of the Cranial kind is for congestions in the throat, and swelling of the uvula, and ailments of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomizing is that the sick person sits between your hands before the sun: and raise his tongue, and look under his tongue on one side for a vein, and on the other side for another vein: and the color of both declines to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Phlebotomize both: and watch that your fingers do not remain on the veins during phlebotomy.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For beneath them are the arteries, and perhaps blood may flow from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	¶ Concerning the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins to be phlebotomized in the elbow are those on which the practice of phlebotomy has run most commonly in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy of these veins is performed according to two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by pricking with a broad phlebotomizingawl: or by cutting to the desired depth: or by slicing with a surgical knife, and this is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is what is suitable for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these there are broad and subtle types according to the width of the veins and their tension. The form of the phlebotomizingawl should be broad, as you can see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening concave, full, flowing, visible, thick, and those that contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomy is of lesser width and finer at the points.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it pertains to phlebotomy of subtle veins, which contain thin yellow blood
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	¶ On the Phlebotomy of Basilicae.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	Basilicae, however, which is one of these three veins, is useful for phlebotomy.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it extracts blood from illnesses that are below the throat and neck, as the chest and abdomen follow. It is suitable for the phlebotomist to use this vein, but he should be careful, for there is an artery beneath it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he errs and adds the incision for phlebotomy too high, he will hit that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore, it is necessary to puncture this vein with the phlebotomus needle, not incising it as with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If however Basilica does not appear with a clear appearance, then it is necessary to feel for it and exchange it for another vein, or you may seek one of its branches: or puncture the place where it is in the arm.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	It is clear and should be punctured with the Anesil phlebotomus needle, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to perform phlebotomy at this place, then you should first compress the arm to find the location until you recognize the pulsating spot.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the location with cautery, afterwards the arm, and incise the vein with a concave incision using the Anesil phlebotomus needle, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware that the percussion does not fall through the space from the site of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, when you tighten the ligature, inflation in the place you marked with cauterization, then that inflation is due to the artery: avoid it therefore.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	And if you see blood springing at the phlebotomy as urine in a child, and it is thin, red blood: then know that it is from the blood of the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Therefore hurry, and place your finger over the long space, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore blood is cut (for it is cut many times), then tie the arm, and release it: and let the patient beware of its motion: and let there be a fear of it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And let it not move for several days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If, however, the blood is not cut and it overcomes you, and there is no medicine present at your moment, then incise the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities are contracted, and the blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the bark of a fig tree, and cut it: take half and tie it over the place of the vein's constriction with a ligature and wool until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is cut, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then observe it with the one whose recall preceded from the place of the powder dischargers' flux of blood. And the cutting off of its blood is not difficult in many disposals, because of the location of the small wound and the possibility of tying from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On Phlebotomy of the Blue Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The blue veins are useful for phlebotomy, which draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because they are composed of a branch of the basilic vein and a branch of the cephalic vein, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it suits the phlebotomist that this vein be above the fear of harm from the phlebotomy, for beneath it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore one makes an incision for phlebotomy and finds a nerve there, it happens that a stupor occurs in it, and the healing of it becomes difficult, and perhaps it is not cured at all.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	And if it is concealed in some people and is subtle and not revealed, then you must make your incision where you are phlebotomizing this vein, cutting with Alnise and avoiding the nerve with your skill.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then incise the vein lengthwise.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the Cephalic Vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein is useful because it draws blood from the head and contributes to diseases of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is proper in this vein, if you wish, to make a puncture for phlebotomy with the olive stick or with the myrtle stick: for it is safer than all other veins, for it is neither an artery nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	Indeed, however, it behooves you at the time of phlebotomy to avoid using the arm only from the elbow and seek a softer place: and it does no harm to him if, on the first percussion, it is not found, that it be repeated over her with phlebotomy several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Indeed, however, perhaps an abscess forms in some people when not subjected to phlebotomy on the first percussion, but that abscess does no harm to him in some way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the usefulness of Phlebotomy and precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy, and its accidents arising from it, which you should consider in its correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First of all, you should know what it is about, namely that phlebotomy is not administered except for the preservation of health, and its continuance, and caution against the approach of illness.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And for phlebotomy to be made in one of the three veins which are in the elbow, namely the Cephalica, and Fusca, and Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And for phlebotomy to be made at the beginning of Spring on an empty stomach, in spring and summer, in autumn and winter after eating when signs of excess are apparent.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And phlebotomy should be made on the first day, or the third day, after three hours have passed from the day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy which is administered during illnesses does not have a fixed hour: but when convenience and necessity summon it, it can be done at night, or during the day, and at any hour, and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not necessary to bleed children until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor is a pregnant woman to be bloodlet until the fourth month through the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor are old people to be bloodlet who have already passed sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When therefore someone wishes to be bloodlet for any reason: it is necessary that he cleanse his intestines before bloodletting with a gentle clyster, if there is much retained feces: so as not to draw from the veins at the time of bloodletting foul and harmful matters from the intestines into the main limbs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor is a patient who has a colic, that is, severe nausea, nor one who is intoxicated, nor one who has just recovered from intoxication, to be bloodlet until that condition is removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor is a patient with dropsy to be bloodlet.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And bloodletting should be avoided again after colic, vomiting, flux of the bowels, increase in copulation, labor, exercise, watchfulness, fasting, and all that dissolves virtue from the bodily or animal substance.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors before that, if blood is thick with food and drinks and medicines: if it is possible for him to do so.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then enter the bath if nothing forbids it: or exercise some exercise, so that the blood may become more subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And set his bloodletting on the third day in the chest, as we have said, and try that his breast is evacuated of all animal maladies on that day: such as oppression, anger, and fear: and of all bodily ailments, such as labor, pain, excess of copulation, and similar conditions.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let there be present on his seat things of whose use custom among men has arisen from the aroma, and fragrance, and pleasure and similar ones according to the quantity possible.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist seat himself on a stool which is higher than the phlebotomy tray: afterwards he should extend his arm, and the phlebotomist should rub it twice or three times with his hand.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tie the ligament with pincers, and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the tie be适度的，因为当捆扎不均匀，或是由于过度紧绷时，就会阻碍血液流动；同样，在过于松弛时，也会阻碍血液流动。
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the tie, let the phlebotomist rub his arms together until the veins swell and become apparent to the touch.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then let the phlebotomist cleanse the patient with a little old oil.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then let the phlebotomist place his left index finger on the vein at the spot where he intends to make the incision, lightly enough so that the vein does not slip and the strike can be made.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because what you find in the veins is like a string fleeing at phlebotomy, and what is full of wind: when you place the patient there, it contracts under the phlebotomist and deceives the phlebotomist, and he does not open the vein. And if he does open it, it will be too tight. Therefore, it is necessary for the phlebotomist to be firm and attentive to all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then let him lower the lancet.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore a vein opens from one incision, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then make another incision at a different place below that spot or above it with haste: if the place does not become abscessed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	And if it becomes abscessed, or the sick person improves, then let him rest for a day, or two days: and do not bind with a ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For it might draw a hot abscess.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither let him enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he may repeat the venesection if he wishes.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	And if the opening is small, or the blood flows slowly: and beware that the quantity you wish to extract does not go beyond the blood: then repeat the venesection at the same opening according to its exact position, and add a little in the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with haste before the place becomes abscessed, for an abscessed place often occurs in many people after a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	And if you see it has already become abscessed, then do not repeat the procedure over it at all, for nothing excuses you in this.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And apply something from the mixture of oil over it: for it will facilitate the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than pure oil, and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the mixture of oil in every venesection where you need to stop the flow of blood: and they do this with Tyriaca Alfarach and Sagzenea when applied from one of them to the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For blood is made subtle and resolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If an apostema occurs at the site of phlebotomy, for it often happens, especially to those who are bled only twice a month, or where there is a small opening in the vein, then hasten and place a sponge soaked in water and salt on the area, heated slightly: and bind it for one hour, for it will be resolved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And you should do this after the blood has exited the vein itself, with its complement, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If something of blackness or greenishness remains in the area after a few days, this is not harmful. And if you wish, place something solutive of aloes or myrrh over it, or something from the juice of mint, that is, calamint or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And indeed, apostemas and swellings often occur at the site of phlebotomy in Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore place your hand on it, then if you find it soft upon compressing it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, be careful to place something from what we have said on it.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood from the artery is flowing from it.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a poultice for it with something containing styptic substances to harden the area.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then attend to it along with the rest of the treatment until it is cured.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to draw blood from every man according to the strength of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which is apparent from the color prevailing over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, let it be allowed to escape until it becomes red: and similarly, if you see it thick, let it be allowed to escape until it becomes thin: and similarly, if it is sharp, let it be allowed to escape until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it must be that one who is full, strong, and needs a single bloodletting, should have the phlebotomy of the vein enlarged, and let the incision be broad: and in him who is weak, the opposite should be done.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it must be that it extracts it alternately and that the opening be narrow: and better for a phlebotomy of a vein is a transverse cut, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood and from cutting the nerve: and it is more commendable and safer than a phlebotomy by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And for those to whom it is accustomed to come upon fainting at phlebotomy, it must be that they eat before phlebotomy a small amount of bread infused in pomegranate water: or secanabin, if it is warmed: and extract from the blood in three alternations, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if it is of a cold complexion, then let him take before phlebotomy bread infused in mulberry syrup, or in aromatic honey syrup, or in fragrant syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	And if fainting occurs at phlebotomy, and the cause of its fainting is the escape of much blood, then it must be that he takes in drink water of meat and fragrant thin syrup: and use aromatic with alum and apply it to his breast with it: and use the rest which we have said in the division in the chapter on fainting from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to evacuate his arm and release his blood in the second method: it ought to be for him who has phlebotomy because of great evacuation, and his strength is weak, that he release the blood gradually according to the quantity of his strength over continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to evacuate his arm and release his blood in the second method, and his body is strong: then let him do this seven or nine hours after his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body to the opposite side of the part that is diseased: it ought to be evacuated for him on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body the blood is already much heated and quickened, and causes a fever: it ought that the blood go out from him in one course, and a large quantity be drawn from him: and the opening be enlarged until syncope occurs: after which you are to preserve all the conditions of phlebotomy: and thou shalt lay thy hand upon his pulse at the course of the blood, that there does not occur death instead of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For this often happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant and falls into negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it ought not to be done when you wish to release the arm and release the blood in the second method, if the vein's opening is already closed, and the exit of the blood becomes difficult, so that it must be pressed upon with frenzy and the incision extended quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For this is very evil, indeed leave it until the second phlebotomy.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with the sharpness of the phlebotome that which has coagulated from the blood in the opening of the vein, and place something of dissolved salt on top of it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place something from Tyroca alfaroch or sagzenea above it, and apply it with gentle compression until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If the vein is already an apostema, then release it and do not tie it until the apostema settles.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If necessity prompts you to bleed the patient a second time, and there is no excuse, then either perform phlebotomy above that place, or on another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But the vein of the arm is phlebotomized at the place of Fuscæ and Basilicæ, when they are not found and are hidden, because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that the patient should place his hand in warm water until it becomes reddened, and the vein should become apparent clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then tie it above with a ligature, but not too tightly in the middle.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then perform the phlebotomy obliquely, not laterally nor along the length: and let the opening be large, and let your phlebotomy pass slightly above the wrist joint.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the exit of blood is prevented, then place the hand in warm water again, and allow the blood to flow into the water until you achieve your necessity.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If you are in the days of summer, then you may excuse yourself from placing the hand in warm water again.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And the blood flows most readily into warm water during the winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this vein is safer for all veins, because there is no pulse vein nor nerve beneath it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy of the Saluatella of the right hand is beneficial for liver diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is, that you tighten the mahason of the hand with a ligament, or with your hand, after you introduce it into hot water until the vein becomes pliable and clearly demonstrated by sensation.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then make the phlebotomy by crossing it.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you puncture it completely, it will not harm him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And conserve, lest you withdraw your hand with the phlebotome.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For beneath it are the nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then repeat the procedure with your hand in hot water, and allow the blood to flow in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not repeat the procedure in hot water, the blood will coagulate at the opening of the vein and be prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When therefore you have drawn off the quantity necessary from the blood, then place oil and salt over the vein: so that it does not harden quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly, you should do this with every tightly drawn vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The ligature for the phlebotomy of this vein is from the left hand: because it is beneficial for spleen diseases. And similarly, do this in the phlebotomy of its counterpart, as you did in the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of phlebotomy for this is that the patient should insert his foot into warm water and make friction over it until the veins become prominent: then ligate above the ankle with iron.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the location of the veins is at the heel, visible opposite the big toe: and from there they branch into many branches on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore phlebotomy should be made on a larger branch of it, or at the heel where it aggregates: for this is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you make the phlebotomy on the face of the foot, then be careful of the nerves that are beneath it on the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy where you make the incision as if you wish to cut through it: and call the phlebotomy Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If the outlet of blood is forbidden, then re-insert his foot into warm water: and permit the blood to flow into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the vein is missed in the first attempt, then repeat with the phlebotomy at a higher location for a short while, for the place is safe, and you should not fear any harm from it, provided you are careful of the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly when Saphena of the other foot is equal.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The place of the Sciatic veins, as we have said, is beside the heel from the wild mulberry side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the aid for its phlebotomy is when there is pain in the hip due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is that the sick person should enter the bath and hasten: and bind the leg from the side of the hip up to above the heel with a thin long bandage: for it would not be apparent otherwise.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it is apparent, then phlebotomize it according to whatever skill is possible for you, or by transversion: it is better, either to incise it, or to cut it by section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its place is safer, and it is hidden in many people to a great extent.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	And if you do not find it and it does not become apparent by any sense: then phlebotomize some branch of it, and that one is the one that appears on the back of the foot and toward the ear: and beware of the nerves, and let the quantity of blood flow that you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then release the bandage, and place skin over the phlebotomy site, and bind the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it is quickly cured.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	¶ Concerning Ventosation and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter XC VIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Wounds are made from horns, and from air, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And ventilation is indeed done according to two methods.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With scarification and bloodletting: and the other is ventilation without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventilation which is done without scarification is according to two methods.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is done with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is done without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventilations administered with scarification and bloodletting are fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is the last part of the head; and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck; and Ventosae Alhagdahim, and they are two laminae of the neck from both sides simultaneously; and Ventosae menti, and it is under the mandible in the lower lip; and Ventosae duarum spatularum; and Ventosae Alachosos above the end of the tail; and Ventosae duorum focilium, and they are in the middle of the two arms; and Ventosae duorum crurium; and Ventosae duarum cauillarum.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And ventilation indeed does not extract blood from you through small veins scattered in the flesh, and for this reason, its virtue does not decline as it does with bloodletting.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	And ventilation should not be administered with or without fire when the illness is caused by congestion until the entire body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity provokes to Ventosation from illness, or on account of custom, we administer it at every hour at the beginning of the month, at the end thereof, and in the middle thereof, and at whatever time it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	Which is because there are persons for whom, when blood is multiplied in their bodies until it needs to be extracted through ventosation, they find heaviness in their head, and so forth.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And among them are those who find fullness and redness in their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And among them are those who find itching in their face, forehead, and darkness, and dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And among them are those who palpitate the place of their ventosation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And among them is one whose laughter is increased.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And among them is one who finds a taste of blood in his mouth: or his tongue swells, and he spits blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And among them is one whose sleep is increased.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And among them is one who sees in his sleep blood, redness, and slain persons, and wounds, and things similar to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see something from these, and properly it is in the middle of the third week: then we order ventosation to be performed after two or three days have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The application of ventosation to the neck is: because it contributes to heaviness in the head, and what flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	Therefore it must be that this is after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this indeed is Ventosa for the place of Phlebotomy Cephalicae.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permissible for one who is of a cold constitution or in whom there is a catarrh to use it.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it causes him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And for this reason, it is not permissible for old people to use it, and those in whose head there are cold diseases.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	He who becomes an assiduous user of it will experience forgetfulness.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for this reason, you should instruct the user of the ventosa to withdraw his hand slightly from below with the ventosa, fearing the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosatio or Alkehel is for the place of Phlebotomy Fuscae and Phlebotomy Basilicae, and for this reason, it alleviates asthma, constriction of breathing, fissures caused by the instrument, coughing, and congestion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it must be that the ventosa alkehel is pressed slightly, for if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosatio alhagdahim alleviates pain occurring in the head, and conjunctivitis, and migraine, and perforation, and toothache: and it is for Phlebotomy Basilicae.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And you should instruct the user of the ventosa not to press his hand with the scarification: lest he hit an artery and cause a blood flow.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Vento-sation under the chin, involves applying alcohol to the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar conditions that are in the mouth: and is placed instead of blood-letting for those that are in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Vento-sation with spatulas, involves applying to the al-chafacham, which results from folding and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Vento-sation of the interior parts of two focilium, involves aid from blood-letting of veins of three: Basilicae, and Fuscae, and Cephalicae: for it draws blood from all those small veins in the flesh: and those small veins draw from other larger veins until the drawing reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it must be instructed to the Vento-sator that he should not proceed too much in scarification: for the area is exposed of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	Vento-sation applied over al-chausos involves treatment of hemorrhoids of the Ani and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it must be instructed to the Vento-sator that the ventosa should be large, and made of air: for the area requires strong suction, and perhaps the fine ventosas will break: and a large scarification should be performed.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	Vento-sas of the legs decrease manifest diminution by drawing blood from the entire body, and bring pain back to old pains in the kidneys, and uterus, and bladder: they provoke menstruation, and bothorcosabinul: and stand instead of blood-letting of the two saphena veins, and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopam in pluribus hominibus.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the aid of Alhorcobeni is near the aid of the two thigh winds.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the thigh winds is such that you should place the wind at first in the empty space and draw it with a tempered suction: and do not prolong the position of the thigh winds, but place them quickly and remove them quickly, so that the humors come to their equal place: and do not cease to repeat this and continue until you see the place already reddening and swelling, and the redness of the blood appear: then therefore incise, and iterate with suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For he who is of tender flesh and few pores should be incised only once, not more: so that the place does not become ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And command the wind applier to enlarge the incision but not too deeply, and regulate the suction for ease, speed, and gentle motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	For if there is thickness in the blood, then you should incise it twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first incision, a way is opened for the subtlety of the blood and its moisture: and in the second, for the thorough extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is exceedingly foul, then make the incision a third time: so that the ultimate purification occurs.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And for the ultimate purpose, when we wish to extract blood gradually or slightly, one incision is sufficient.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to perform the bloodletting of many, we incise with multiple cuts.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we find the blood is thick: then it is necessary to incise with a deep cut. And the equal limit in incision is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What should be administered from oils during the positioning of Ventsorae, and what the ventosandus should beware.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	For those whose skin is thick, hard, and dark, and whose pores are narrow, it is necessary to apply the areas of Ventsorae with opening, soothing, and resolving oils. If it is in the summer season, such as olive oil, or floral oil, or almond oil, or cucumber seed oil.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the winter season, then almond oil, or lily oil, or chamomile oil, or saffron: and similar for them.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If the excess is thick and cold, then use bitter almond oil, or balsam oil, or white almond oil, or eucalyptus oil: and similar for them.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If the ventosandus has large pores and tender flesh, then it is necessary to prohibit them from using oil. After the treatment of Ventsorae, these individuals should wash the areas with rose water, or cold water, or solar water, or cucumber water, or purslane water: and similar for them.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	For those whose blood is of great humidity, they should wash the Ventsorae with vinegar, or myrtle water, or sumach water: and similar for them.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	Whose superfluities are large, let him apply his suction cups with old wine, or with saffron water, or a decoction of angelica, or chamomile, and to similar things.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it must be observed that the suction should be applied in a bath, or at the site of the bath, or it must be administered after exiting the bath for one hour, or two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not advisable for someone to sleep after suction therapy.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is to be considered regarding the regulation of Ventosandus or phlebotomy before suction therapy.
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after this, you should consider first: if the suction or phlebotomy is cholic and overpowering the blood by its sharpness and inflammation, then it should receive cooling remedies such as pomegranate juice. Additionally, it should also take endive with vinegar and lettuce, and fennel and rue, and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And provide him with light foods, and sheep's meat, and seasoned foods with herbs: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And for one with a cold complexion, he should take in his drink a syrup made from honey, or from ammi seed, or fennel seed: and he should take medium fragrant wine, which is between old and new: and it should be ordered that he eat in moderation.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And provide him with light foods, and cabbage: and young birds, that is, small birds: and chicks.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it must be that the drink on the day of suction and phlebotomy is more than the food: and it should be given in drinks to some people at Tyrian hours, namely alfaroch, or a medicine from musk, that is, mastic, or alecost before suction and before phlebotomy, or after them, to strengthen the principal members and thin the blood.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it is not proper for them to take it in heated drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	¶ Concerning Ventuses Without Scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	But ventuses that are without scarification are those applied to the liver, spleen, and foot, and to the abdomen, navel, and spinal regions: for these parts do not tolerate scarification upon them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And they are not sought for except by contact from a bloody member to another member: as we apply the ventus to the breasts in the illness of nasal bleeding.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them so that the cold and penetrating ventus affects the member: as we apply the ventus to the abdomen and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it rarifies the member, and heats it, and removes pain because it resolves that ventus.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	And it is also applied to the kidneys when obstruction or stone occurs there.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For by the virtue of its attraction, it perhaps opens the obstruction or removes the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And similarly, it does so when applied to the liver and spleen during ventus that is to be applied to both of them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these ventuses are administered with empty cups using only sections.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are administered full of warm water in diseases of the pleura: and this is so that the ventus is filled, and contains much water, or hot water alone, or water in which herbs suitable for the condition have been decocted.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the size of its opening be two fingers wide, as we have formed it: and its depth shall be half a palm in length. In its side, at a place near the middle, let there be a small hole for the needle according to its size: make it of copper or brass, thick, thin, equal, bright: so that it does not hurt the member where it is placed upon it. Let there be a rod across its middle of copper or iron where the candle with fire is placed.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this large ventosae is made, greater than that which we have narrated, and slightly smaller than that, according to the illnesses and age of him who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For the ventosae of children and slender persons are different from those of adults and corpulent bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of placing this ventosae with fire upon the member is to ignite a small wick from linen or a small candle of tallow, and place it at the middle of the cross rod which is in the middle of the ventosae: so that the flame is near the lower part of the ventosae, so that the body of the ill person is not burned.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then it is placed upon the member: and the finger is placed over the hole as I said, until when we hold the ventosae: whenever we need to, we remove the finger, and the vapor will exit through that hole, and the ventosae will immediately be removed.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then the wick is ignited according to its size, and repeat it if you need to do so.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	In ventosa, however, which is administered in the illness of pleuritis, there is no cross rod, nor a hole: and it is not administered unless filled with water and placed only on the limb.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this ventosa is better the more it is large so as to hold much water.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	¶ Concerning the Suspension of Sanguisugae.
Caput XCIX.	Head XCIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Sanguisugae are not administered in many cases, except where the application of suction cups to the limbs is impossible due to their thinness, such as the lip, the gums, and similar areas.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or on a limb that is bare of flesh, such as the finger, the nose, and similar areas.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is: to use the veners from sanguisugae that are in sweet and clean water, free from putrefaction.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they are left to rest in sweet water by day and night until they become flaccid, and nothing remains in their cavities.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body is evacuated first with phlebotomy and with suction cups.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then cleanse the affected limb until it becomes reddened.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Then place them upon it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When therefore they are filled and fall, and suction is possible with the suction cup at that place, then it is more effective for treatment. And if not, then wash the area with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then, when much water is added, and it is rubbed and expressed.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the course of the blood is prolonged after the fall of Sugardrops, and this is flowing out: then pour a linen cloth in cold water, and place it above, until the flowing stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood is increased, then powder zegi ground, or gall, and similar substances from styptic materials above it until the blood stops.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or place halves of peeled fava beans above the wound, and let them remain until the fava beans adhere to the place, for the blood will stop flowing.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And it is necessary, when required, to change Sugardrops if possible.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If Sugardrops are prohibited due to suspension, then the area should be cleansed with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or prick with a sharp object until something comes out from the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then they should be placed, for they adhere immediately to something from the blood when they sense it.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When therefore you wish them to fall, powder something from ground aloe, or salt, or ashes above them, and they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	## End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	## Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part III.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	## General Word on Restoration, Dislocation, and the Cure of Twisting and Similar Conditions.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This Chapter is also often necessary in the art of Medicine, and is about the restoration of fractures and dislocations in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know, my Sons, that the ignorant physicians and the common people boast of this Chapter, and those who have never examined an ancient book, nor read a single letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And for this reason, this method is absent from our local medical sciences.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I have never come across it that was entirely good, and I did not acquire what I acquired except due to the length of reading the ancient books, and the study beyond understanding them until I extracted that knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then I adhered to experience and the study through the length of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described to you from that in this Chapter all that my science contains: and for what my experience has not reached, after abbreviating it for you and freeing it from the occupation of extension, and abbreviating it at the end of abbreviation, and showing it at the end of declination: and formed many forms from the forms of instruments which are administered in it, as there is addition of declination, just as I did in the two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	In summary, and collections concerning fractures of bones, from those of which a preliminary discussion is necessary before we begin the recollection of fractured and various other bones.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
